ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I learned about the many perspectives surrounding vaccines that have been introduced and retained throughout history.

I gained a much deeper understanding of the history of vaccination. Particularly interesting, was the history of smallpox vaccination, and some of the early efforts to stimulate widespread immunization.
I learned a lot more about how vaccine hesitancy arose, most specifically in the United States and the common themes surrounding vaccine hesitancy throughout history.
lots abt the history of vaccines and skepticism

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: I loved the topics covered during the course. We took a generally chronological journey through vaccine history and then finally related those historical perspectives to the current COVID era. One aspect that I think could be improved is if we dove more deeply into readings during class. Sometimes, we got onto tangents and drifted away from the readings.

Strengths: amazing prof, great readings, really engaging assignments. Prof Schwartz really cares about running a class that is meaningful and fun. 

Weaknesses: wish we had more global content or non west content to look at. Class got a little stagnant after awhile, too.
I thought this is a very well balanced course, and I have no major criticisms.

Strengths: the class is organized well. I liked the "case-study" like aspects where we spent each week progressing through different eras/vaccines 

Weaknesses: Though this is a seminar style course, sometimes I felt some visual timelines of the events we talked about would've helped make discussions more digestible

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: I would recommend this course! It provides so many perspectives that are so important to understand as we have lived through the covid pandemic era. It really helped me consider the perspectives of others even when I dont necessarily agree with those perspectives.
Yes! This is a great course with a world-class prof. Do the work and you'll get a good grade.
I would absolutely recommend this course to anyone, interested in public health and the history of health interventions.
If you are interested in learning about vaccine hesitancy, its origins, trends, and continuities, then yes.
